Comment: I double-step my king's pawn to free his bishop and my queen...
...and my opponent single-steps his, with the French Defence...
...and I double-step my queen's pawn to give her and her bishop more freedom, still keeping with the French Defence...
...and he does likewise, still with the French Defence...
...and I capture it, going to the exchange variation...
...but he breaks it by recapturing with his queen.
Now I bring out my knight on the queenside to attack her...
...forcing her back to her base.
Now I develop my kingside knight, giving me some control of the centre...
...and he develops his kingside knight to contest the light squares in the centre...
...and I now bring out my bishop, and decide to check the king...
...forcing his light-square bishop's pawn out to block...
...so I retreat it one square.
He brings out his dark-square bishop to pin down my knight...
...so I bring up mine to unpin it, and to keep a reasonable pawn structure should the bishop capture...
...and he castles kingside...
...so I copy him...
...and he attacks my light-square bishop with a pawn...
...so again I retreat it one square.
He now brings out his quenside knight and connects them...
